entities.title: Arthur Wesley Dow
entities.description: Arthur Wesley Dow was an American painter, printmaker, photographer and influential arts educator.

entities.title: René Lalique
entities.description: René Jules Lalique was a French glass designer known for his creations of glass art, perfume bottles, vases, jewellery, chandeliers, clocks and automobile hood ornaments.

heading: Births
txt: Stanislas de Guaita, French poet and author (d. 1897)

entities.title: Stanislas de Guaita
entities.description: Stanislas De Guaita was a French poet based in Paris, an expert on esotericism and European mysticism, and an active member of the Rosicrucian Order. He was very celebrated and successful in his time. He had many disputes with other people who were involved with occultism and magic. Occultism and magic were part of his novels.

heading: Births
txt: William Bate Hardy, English biologist and academic (d. 1934)

entities.title: William Bate Hardy
entities.description: Sir William Bate Hardy, FRS was a British biologist and food scientist. The William Bate Hardy Prize is named in his honour.

heading: Births
txt: Felix-Raymond-Marie Rouleau, Canadian cardinal (d. 1931)

entities.title: Felix-Raymond-Marie Rouleau
entities.description: Félix-Raymond-Marie Rouleau was a Canadian Cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church. He served as Archbishop of Quebec from 1926 until his death, and was elevated to the cardinalate in 1927.

heading: Births
txt: Levon Shant, Armenian author, poet, and playwright (d. 1951)

entities.title: Levon Shant
entities.description: Levon Shant was an Armenian playwright, novelist, poet and founder of the Hamazkayin Armenian Educational and Cultural Society.

txt: Erich Mühsam, German author, poet, and playwright (d. 1934)

entities.title: Erich Mühsam
entities.description: Erich Mühsam was a German-Jewish antimilitarist anarchist essayist, poet and playwright. He emerged at the end of World War I as one of the leading agitators for a federated Bavarian Soviet Republic, for which he served 5 years in prison.

heading: Births
txt: Karl Staaf, Swedish pole vaulter and hammer thrower (d. 1953)

entities.title: Karl Staaf
entities.description: Karl Gustaf Staaf was a Swedish track and field athlete and tug of war competitor who competed at the 1900 Summer Olympics. He was born in Stockholm.

heading: Births
txt: J. G. Parry-Thomas, Welsh race car driver and engineer (d. 1927)

entities.title: J. G. Parry-Thomas
entities.description: John Godfrey Parry-Thomas was a Welsh engineer and motor-racing driver who at one time held the land speed record. He was the first driver to be killed in pursuit of the land speed record.

heading: Births
txt: Athenagoras I of Constantinople (d. 1972)

entities.title: Athenagoras I of Constantinople
entities.description: Athenagoras I (Greek: Αθηναγόρας Αʹ, born Aristocles Matthew Spyrou, initially the Greek archbishop in North America, was the 268th Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople, from 1948 to 1972.

entities.title: Hans Richter (artist)
entities.description: Hans Richter was a German painter, graphic artist, avant-gardist, film-experimenter and producer. He was born in Berlin into a well-to-do family and died in Minusio, near Locarno, Switzerland.

txt: Gerhard Ritter, German historian and academic (d. 1967)

heading: Births
txt: Anthony Fokker, Dutch engineer and businessman, founded Fokker Aircraft Manufacturer (d. 1939)

entities.title: Anthony Fokker
entities.description: Anton Herman Gerard "Anthony" Fokker was a Dutch aviation pioneer, aviation entrepreneur, aircraft designer, and aircraft manufacturer. He is most famous for the fighter aircraft he produced in Germany during the First World War such as the Eindecker monoplanes, the Dr.1 triplane and the D.VII biplane.

entities.title: Fokker
entities.description: Fokker was a Dutch aircraft manufacturer named after its founder, Anthony Fokker. The company operated under several different names, starting out in 1912 in Schwerin, Germany, moving to the Netherlands in 1919.

heading: Births
txt: Donald Wills Douglas, Sr., American businessman, founded the Douglas Aircraft Company (d. 1981)

entities.title: Donald Wills Douglas, Sr.
entities.description: Donald Wills Douglas Sr. was an American aircraft industrialist and engineer.

entities.title: Douglas Aircraft Company
entities.description: The Douglas Aircraft Company was an American aerospace manufacturer based in Southern California. It was founded in 1921 by Donald Wills Douglas Sr. and later merged with McDonnell Aircraft in 1967 to form McDonnell Douglas, when it then operated as a division of McDonnell Douglas. McDonnell Douglas later merged with Boeing in 1997.

heading: Births
txt: Lowell Thomas, American journalist and author (d. 1981)

heading: Births
txt: Dudley Nichols, American director, producer, and screenwriter (d. 1960)

entities.title: Dudley Nichols
entities.description: Dudley Nichols was an American screenwriter and director. He was the first person to decline an Academy Award, as part of a boycott to gain recognition for the Screen Writers Guild; he would later accept his Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay in 1938.

heading: Births
txt: Jeanne Hébuterne, French painter and author (d. 1920)

entities.title: Jeanne Hébuterne
entities.description: Jeanne Hébuterne was a French painter and art model best known as the frequent subject and common-law wife of the artist Amedeo Modigliani. She took her own life two days after Modigliani died, and is now buried beside him.

heading: Births
txt: Leo Robin, American composer and songwriter (d. 1984)

entities.title: Leo Robin
entities.description: Leo Robin was an American composer, lyricist and songwriter. He is probably best known for collaborating with Ralph Rainger on the 1938 Oscar-winning song "Thanks for the Memory", sung by Bob Hope and Shirley Ross in the film The Big Broadcast of 1938.

heading: Births
txt: Pier Giorgio Frassati, Italian activist (d. 1925)

entities.title: Pier Giorgio Frassati
entities.description: Pier Giorgio Frassati was an Italian Roman Catholic social activist and a member from the Third Order of Saint Dominic. He was dedicated to social justice issues and joined several charitable organizations, including Catholic Action and the St Vincent de Paul Society, to better aid the poor and less fortunate living in his hometown of Turin; he put his own pious beliefs into practice to cater to t

heading: Births
txt: Julien Torma, French author, poet, and playwright (d. 1933)

entities.title: Julien Torma
entities.description: Julien Torma was credited as a French writer, playwright and poet who was part of the Dadaist movement.

heading: Births
txt: Mickey Cochrane, American baseball player and manager (d. 1962)

entities.title: Mickey Cochrane
entities.description: Gordon Stanley "Mickey" Cochrane, nicknamed "Black Mike", was an American professional baseball player, manager and coach. He played in Major League Baseball as a catcher for the Philadelphia Athletics and Detroit Tigers. Cochrane was considered one of the best catchers in baseball history and is a member of the Baseball Hall of Fame.

txt: Kurt Georg Kiesinger, German lawyer, politician and Chancellor of Germany (d. 1988)

entities.title: Kurt Georg Kiesinger
entities.description: Kurt Georg Kiesinger was a German politician who served as Chancellor of Germany from 1 December 1966 to 21 October 1969. Before he became Chancellor he was a Nazi Party member, served as Minister President of Baden-Württemberg from 1958 to 1966 and as President of the Federal Council from 1962 to 1963. He was Chairman of the Christian Democratic Union from 1967 to 1971.

entities.title: Chancellor of Germany
entities.description: The chancellor of Germany, officially the federal chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany, is the head of government and chief executive of Germany, as well as the commander in chief of the German Armed Forces during wartime. The chancellor is elected by the Bundestag on the proposal of the federal president and without debate.

heading: Births
txt: Erwin Komenda, Austrian car designer and engineer (d. 1966)

heading: Births
txt: Marcel-Marie Desmarais, Canadian preacher, missionary, and author (d. 1994)

entities.title: Marcel-Marie Desmarais
entities.description: Marcel-Marie Desmarais,, was a Quebec writer, preacher and broadcaster. A member of the Roman Catholic Dominican Order, he became a personality through his popular books and radio and TV programs in Quebec. He was also sent as missionary to Brazil during the 1940s.

heading: Births
txt: William M. Branham, American minister and theologian (d. 1965)

entities.title: William M. Branham
entities.description: William Marrion Branham was an American Christian minister and faith healer who initiated the post–World War II healing revival. He left a lasting impact on televangelism and the modern Charismatic movement and is recognized as the "principal architect of restorationist thought" for Charismatics by some Christian historians. At the time they were held, his inter-denominational meetings were the la

heading: Births
txt: Hermann Lang, German race car driver (d. 1987)

entities.description: Boris Uladzimiravich Kit was a Belarusian-American rocket scientist.

entities.description: Belarusian Americans are Americans who are of total or partial Belarusian ancestry.

entities.description: Feodor Felix Konrad Lynen was a German biochemist. In 1964 he won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine together with Konrad Bloch for their discoveries concerning the mechanism and regulation of cholesterol and fatty acid metabolism while he was director of the Max-Planck Institute for Cellular Chemistry in Munich.

entities.description: Tadeusz Kantor was a Polish painter, assemblage and Happenings artist, set designer and theatre director. Kantor is renowned for his revolutionary theatrical performances in Poland and abroad. Laureate of Witkacy Prize - Critics' Circle Award (1989).

entities.description: (Mary) Leonora Carrington OBE was a British-born Mexican artist, surrealist painter, and novelist. She lived most of her adult life in Mexico City and was one of the last surviving participants in the Surrealist movement of the 1930s. Carrington was also a founding member of the women's liberation movement in Mexico during the 1970s.

heading: Births

entities.title: Alfredo Ovando Candía
entities.description: Alfredo Ovando Candía was the Commander of the Bolivian Air Forces and ambassador who served as the 48th President of Bolivia twice nonconsecutively, first as co-president with René Barrientos from 1965 to 1966 and then as de facto president from 1969 to 1970.

entities.title: President of Bolivia
entities.description: The President of Bolivia, officially known as the President of the Plurinational State of Bolivia, is head of state and head of government of Bolivia and the Captain General of the Armed Forces of Bolivia.

heading: Births
txt: Georgios Mylonas, Greek politician, 11th Greek Minister of Culture (d. 1998)

entities.title: Georgios Mylonas
entities.description: Georgios Mylonas was a Greek Center Union politician and government minister. He was a close aide to Greek statesman and premier George Papandreou, and was repeatedly elected deputy for the Ioannina seat with the Center Union. Mylonas had served as an undersecretary to the premier's office and education undersecretary from 1963 to 1965. He assumed the transport ministry in the first post-junta gov

entities.title: Ministry of Culture and Sport (Greece)

The incumbent minister is Lina Mendoni. The Deputy Minister for Modern Culture is Nikolas Giatromanolakis, and the Deputy Minister for Sports is Lefteris Avgenakis.

Willis formed an extremely prolific partnership with his life-long friend Keith Waterhouse producing over 250 works. entities.title: Miss World Puerto Rico 2008
entities.description: Miss World Puerto Rico 2008, The annual competition was held in Puerto Rico, televised live by Telemundo Puerto Rico. Miss World Puerto Rico 2007, Jennifer Guevara Campos of Orocovis was succeeded by Ivonne Orsini, from San Juan who won the Miss World Puerto Rico 2008 title on March 27, 2008. Orsini will represent Puerto Rico at the Miss World 2008.

entities.title: Ken (singer)
entities.description: Lee Jae-hwan, better known by his stage name Ken (Korean: 켄), is a South Korean singer and actor, signed under Jellyfish Entertainment. He is one of the members in the South Korean boy group VIXX, and has been widely praised for his unique, soulful, and husky vocal tone. Ken began his acting career in 2014 in MBC Every 1's comedy drama Boarding House No. 24 as Lee Jae-hwan.

entities.title: Peyton List (actress, born 1998)
entities.description: Peyton Roi List is an American actress and model. List began her career as a child model, modeling for tween magazines and companies. She made her acting debut with the film 27 Dresses (2008), and soon became recognized for playing Holly Hills in the Diary of a Wimpy Kid film series.

heading: Births
txt: Valentina Tronel, French child singer, winner of the Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2020

entities.title: Valentina (singer)
entities.description: Valentina Tronel, better known as simply Valentina, is a French singer who, in 2016, took part in the French version of The Voice Kids. Since 2018, she has been part of the child musical group Kids United Nouvelle Génération, with whom she has recorded the albums Au bout de nos rêves (2018) and L'Hymne de la vie (2019). In 2020, she represented France with the winning song "J'imagine" at the Junio

entities.title: Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2020
entities.description: The Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2020 was the 18th edition of the annual Junior Eurovision Song Contest, organised by Telewizja Polska (TVP) and the European Broadcasting Union (EBU). The contest took place on 29 November 2020, and was held in Warsaw, Poland, following the country's victory at the 2019 contest. This was the first time the contest was held in the same country for two consecutive

heading: Deaths
txt: Prudentius, bishop of Troyes

entities.title: Prudentius of Troyes
entities.description: Prudentius was bishop of Troyes, a chronicler and an opponent of Hincmar of Reims in the controversy on predestination.

entities.title: Roman Catholic Diocese of Troyes
entities.description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Troyes is a diocese of the Latin Rite of the Roman Catholic Church in Troyes, France. The diocese now comprises the département of Aube. Erected in the 4th century, the diocese is currently suffragan to the Archdiocese of Reims. It was re-established in 1802 as a suffragan of the Archbishopric of Paris, when it comprised the départements of Aube and Yonne and its bish

heading: Deaths
txt: Saint Methodius, Byzantine missionary and saint (b. 815)

entities.title: Saints Cyril and Methodius
entities.description: Cyril and Methodius (815–885) were two brothers and Byzantine Christian theologians and missionaries. For their work evangelizing the Slavs, they are known as the "Apostles to the Slavs".

heading: Deaths
txt: Pei Che, chancellor of the Tang Dynasty

entities.title: Pei Che
entities.description: Pei Che (裴澈), courtesy name Shenyuan (深源), was an official of the late Tang dynasty, serving as a chancellor during the reigns of Emperor Xizong and the pretender to the throne Li Yun. After Li Yun was defeated and executed, Pei was also executed for his service under Li Yun.

entities.title: Chancellor of the Tang dynasty
entities.description: The chancellor was a semi-formally designated office position for a number of high-level officials at one time during the Tang dynasty. This list includes chancellors of the reign of Wu Zetian, which she referred to as the "Zhou dynasty" (周), rather than "Tang" (唐).

heading: Deaths
txt: Liu Churang, Chinese general and chief of staff (b. 881)

entities.title: Liu Churang
entities.description: Liu Churang, courtesy name Deqian (德謙), was a general of the Chinese Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms Period states Later Tang and Later Jin, serving as a chief of staff (Shumishi) during the reign of Later Jin's founding emperor Shi Jingtang.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nasr II, ruler (amir) of the Samanid Empire (b. 906)

entities.title: Samanid Empire
entities.description: The Samanid Empire was a Sunni Iranian empire from 819 to 999. The empire was centred in Khorasan and Transoxiana; at its greatest extent encompassing modern-day Afghanistan, large parts of Iran, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, and parts of Kazakhstan and Pakistan.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frederick II, duke of Swabia (b. 1090)

entities.title: Frederick II, Duke of Swabia
entities.description: Frederick II, called the One-Eyed, was Duke of Swabia from 1105 until his death, the second from the Hohenstaufen dynasty. His younger brother Conrad was elected King of the Romans in 1138.

entities.title: Duchy of Swabia
entities.description: The Duchy of Swabia was one of the five stem duchies of the medieval German Kingdom. It arose in the 10th century in the southwestern area that had been settled by Alemanni tribes in Late Antiquity.

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard I, king of England (b. 1157)

entities.title: Richard I of England
entities.description: Richard I was King of England from 1189 until his death in 1199. He also ruled as Duke of Normandy, Aquitaine and Gascony, Lord of Cyprus, and Count of Poitiers, Anjou, Maine, and Nantes, and was overlord of Brittany at various times during the same period. He was the third of five sons of King Henry II of England and Eleanor of Aquitaine and seemed unlikely to become king, but all his brothers ex

entities.title: Kingdom of England
entities.description: The Kingdom of England was a sovereign state on the island of Great Britain from 12 July 927, when it emerged from various Anglo-Saxon kingdoms, until 1 May 1707, when it united with Scotland to form the Kingdom of Great Britain. The Kingdom of England was among the most powerful states in Europe during the medieval period.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Marshal, 2nd Earl of Pembroke

entities.title: William Marshal, 2nd Earl of Pembroke
entities.description: William Marshal, 2nd Earl of Pembroke was a medieval English nobleman and was one of Magna Carta sureties. He fought during the First Barons' War and was present at the Battle of Lincoln (1217) alongside his father William Marshal, 1st Earl of Pembroke, who led the English troops in that battle. He commissioned the first biography of a medieval knight to be written, called L'Histoire de Guillaume

heading: Deaths
txt: Guillaume de Sonnac, Grand Master of the Knights Templar

entities.title: Guillaume de Sonnac
entities.description: Guillaume de Sonnac was Grand Master of the Knights Templar from 1247 to 1250.

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter of Verona, Italian priest and saint (b. 1206)

entities.title: Peter of Verona
entities.description: Peter of Verona, also known as Saint Peter Martyr and Saint Peter of Verona, was a 13th-century Italian Catholic priest. He was a Dominican friar and a celebrated preacher. He served as Inquisitor in Lombardy, was killed by an assassin, and was canonized as a Catholic saint 11 months after his death, making this the fastest canonization in history.

heading: Deaths
txt: Basil, emperor of Trebizond (Turkey)

entities.title: Basil of Trebizond
entities.description: Basil Megas Komnenos was Emperor of Trebizond from August 1332 until his death in 1340. Although Basil's reign was a period of stability during the civil war that dominated the pocket empire during the second quarter of the 14th century, some of that conflict had its origins in his marital actions.

entities.title: Empire of Trebizond
entities.description: The Empire of Trebizond, or Trapezuntine Empire, was a monarchy and one of three successor rump states of the Byzantine Empire that flourished during the 13th through 15th centuries, consisting of the far northeastern corner of Anatolia and the southern Crimea. The empire was formed in 1204 with the help of the Georgian queen Tamar after the Georgian expedition in Chaldia and Paphlagonia, commande

entities.title: Turkey
entities.description: Turkey, officially the Republic of Turkey, is a country straddling Western Asia and Southeast Europe. It shares borders with Greece and Bulgaria to the northwest; the Black Sea to the north; Georgia to the northeast; Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Iran to the east; Iraq to the southeast; Syria and the Mediterranean Sea to the south; and the Aegean Sea to the west. Istanbul, the largest city, is the fina

heading: Deaths
txt: James I, count of La Marche (b. 1319)

entities.title: James I, Count of La Marche
entities.description: James I of Bourbon, was the son of Louis I, Duke of Bourbon and Mary of Avesnes. He was Count of Ponthieu from 1351 to 1360, and Count of La Marche from 1341 to his death.

entities.title: County of La Marche
entities.description: The County of La Marche was a medieval French county, approximately corresponding to the modern département of Creuse.

heading: Deaths
txt: Preczlaw of Pogarell, Cardinal and Bishop of Wrocław (b. 1310)

entities.title: Preczlaw of Pogarell
entities.description: Przecław of Pogorzela was a Cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church and Bishop of Wrocław from 1342–1376.

entities.title: Cardinal (Catholicism)
entities.description: Cardinals are the most senior members of the clergy of the Catholic Church, being second in precedence only to the Pope. They are appointed to the rank of cardinal in addition to their existing position within the Church. Collectively, they constitute the College of Cardinals, and are appointed for life.

entities.title: Bishop of Wrocław
entities.description: Bishops of the Wrocław Bishopric, Prince-Bishopric (1290–1918), and Archdiocese.

heading: Deaths
txt: Matthias Corvinus, King of Hungary and Croatia from 1458 to 1490 (b. 1443)

entities.title: Matthias Corvinus
entities.description: Matthias Corvinus, also called Matthias I, was King of Hungary and Croatia from 1458 to 1490. After conducting several military campaigns, he was elected King of Bohemia in 1469 and adopted the title Duke of Austria in 1487. He was the son of John Hunyadi, Regent of Hungary, who died in 1456. In 1457, Matthias was imprisoned along with his older brother, Ladislaus Hunyadi, on the orders of King La

entities.title: King of Hungary
entities.description: The King of Hungary was the ruling head of state of the Kingdom of Hungary from 1000 to 1918. The style of title "Apostolic King of Hungary" was endorsed by Pope Clement XIII in 1758 and used afterwards by all Monarchs of Hungary.

entities.title: List of rulers of Croatia
entities.description: This is a complete list of rulers of Croatia under domestic ethnic and elected dynasties during the Croatian Kingdom (925–1918). This article follows the monarch's title number according to Hungarian succession for convenience. For example, the Hungarian monarch Béla IV is according to Croatian succession correctly titled Béla III. This is because Hungarians had a king named Béla prior to the inc

heading: Deaths
txt: Raphael, Italian painter and architect (b. 1483)

entities.title: Raphael
entities.description: Raffaello Sanzio da Urbino, known as Raphael, was an Italian painter and architect of the High Renaissance. His work is admired for its clarity of form, ease of composition, and visual achievement of the Neoplatonic ideal of human grandeur. Together with Michelangelo and Leonardo da Vinci, he forms the traditional trinity of great masters of that period.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry Stafford, 1st Earl of Wiltshire, English nobleman (b. 1479)

entities.title: Henry Stafford, 1st Earl of Wiltshire
entities.description: Henry Stafford, 1st Earl of Wiltshire was an English peer.

txt: Albrecht Dürer, German painter, engraver, and mathematician (b. 1471)

entities.title: Albrecht Dürer
entities.description: Albrecht Dürer, sometimes spelled in English as Durer or Duerer, was a German painter, printmaker, and theorist of the German Renaissance. Born in Nuremberg, Dürer established his reputation and influence across Europe in his twenties due to his high-quality woodcut prints. He was in contact with the major Italian artists of his time, including Raphael, Giovanni Bellini and Leonardo da Vinci, and

heading: Deaths
txt: Joachim Vadian, Swiss scholar and politician (b. 1484)

entities.title: Joachim Vadian
entities.description: Joachim Vadian, born as Joachim von Watt, was a humanist, scholar, mayor and reformer in St. Gallen.

entities.title: Francis Walsingham
entities.description: Sir Francis Walsingham was principal secretary to Queen Elizabeth I of England from 20 December 1573 until his death and is popularly remembered as her "spymaster".

entities.title: Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster
entities.description: The Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster is a ministerial office in the Government of the United Kingdom that includes as part of its duties the administration of the estates and rents of the Duchy of Lancaster.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry Barrowe, English Puritan and separatist (b. 1550)

entities.title: Henry Barrowe
entities.description: Henry Barrow was an English Separatist Puritan, or Brownist, executed for his views. He led the London Underground Church from 1587 to 1593, spending most of that time in prison, and wrote numerous works of Brownist apologetics, most notably A Brief Discoverie of the False Church.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Stow, English historian and author (b. 1525)

entities.title: John Stow
entities.description: John Stow was an English historian and antiquarian. He wrote a series of chronicles of English history, published from 1565 onwards under such titles as The Summarie of Englyshe Chronicles, The Chronicles of England, and The Annales of England; and also A Survey of London. A. L. Rowse has described him as "one of the best historians of that age; indefatigable in the trouble he took, thorough and c

heading: Deaths
txt: Edward Seymour, 1st Earl of Hertford (b. 1539)

entities.title: Edward Seymour, 1st Earl of Hertford
entities.description: Edward Seymour, 1st Earl of Hertford, 1st Baron Beauchamp, KG, of Wulfhall and Tottenham House in Great Bedwyn, Wiltshire, of Hatch Beauchamp in Somerset, of Netley Abbey, Hampshire, and of Hertford House, Cannon Row in Westminster, is most noted for incurring the displeasure of Queen Elizabeth I by more than one clandestine marriage.

heading: Deaths
txt: Domenico Zampieri (Domenichino), Italian painter (b. 1581)

entities.title: Domenichino
entities.description: Domenico Zampieri, known by the diminutive Domenichino after his shortness, was an Italian Baroque painter of the Bolognese School of painters.

entities.title: David Blondel
entities.description: David Blondel was a French Protestant clergyman, historian and classical scholar.

entities.title: Leonora Baroni
entities.description: Leonora Baroni was an Italian singer, theorbist, lutenist, viol player, and composer.

entities.title: John Winthrop the Younger
entities.description: John Winthrop the Younger was an early governor of the Connecticut Colony, and he played a large role in the merger of several separate settlements into the unified colony.

entities.title: List of colonial governors of Connecticut
entities.description: The territory of the United States state of Connecticut was first settled by Europeans in the 1620s, when Dutch traders established trading posts on the Connecticut River. English settlers, mainly Puritans fleeing repression in England, began to arrive in the 1630s, and a number of separate colonies were established. The first was the Saybrook Colony in 1635, based at the mouth of the Connecticut;

heading: Deaths
txt: Arthur Annesley, 1st Earl of Anglesey, Irish-English politician (b. 1614)

entities.title: Arthur Annesley, 1st Earl of Anglesey
entities.description: Arthur Annesley, 1st Earl of Anglesey PC was an Anglo-Irish royalist statesman. After short periods as President of the Council of State and Treasurer of the Navy, he served as Lord Privy Seal between 1673 and 1682 for Charles II. He succeeded his father as 2nd Viscount Valentia in 1660, and he was created Earl of Anglesey in 1661.

heading: Deaths
txt: Willem van de Velde the Younger, Dutch-English painter (b. 1633)

entities.title: Willem van de Velde the Younger
entities.description: Willem van de Velde the Younger was a Dutch marine painter, the son of Willem van de Velde the Elder, who also specialised in maritime art.

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard Rawlinson, English minister and historian (b. 1690)

entities.title: Richard Rawlinson
entities.description: Richard Rawlinson FRS was an English clergyman and antiquarian collector of books and manuscripts, which he bequeathed to the Bodleian Library, Oxford.

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis IX, Landgrave of Hesse-Darmstadt (b. 1719)

entities.title: Louis IX, Landgrave of Hesse-Darmstadt
entities.description: Louis IX of Hesse-Darmstadt was the Landgrave of Hesse-Darmstadt from 1768 - 1790. He was a son of Louis VIII, Landgrave of Hesse-Darmstadt, and Charlotte of Hanau-Lichtenberg and Müntzenberg.

heading: Deaths
txt: Vladimir Borovikovsky, Ukrainian-Russian painter and educator (b. 1757)

entities.title: Vladimir Borovikovsky
entities.description: Vladimir Lukich Borovikovsky was a prominent Russian Imperial artist of Ukrainian background, who served at the court of Catherine the Great and dominated portraiture in the Russian Empire at the turn of the 19th century.

heading: Deaths
txt: Niels Henrik Abel, Norwegian mathematician and theorist (b. 1802)

entities.title: Niels Henrik Abel
entities.description: Niels Henrik Abel was a Norwegian mathematician who made pioneering contributions in a variety of fields. His most famous single result is the first complete proof demonstrating the impossibility of solving the general quintic equation in radicals. This question was one of the outstanding open problems of his day, and had been unresolved for over 250 years. He was also an innovator in the field of

heading: Deaths
txt: Adamantios Korais, Greek philosopher and scholar (b. 1748)

entities.title: Adamantios Korais
entities.description: Adamantios Korais or Koraïs was a Greek scholar credited with laying the foundations of Modern Greek literature and a major figure in the Greek Enlightenment. His activities paved the way for the Greek War of Independence and the emergence of a purified form of the Greek language, known as Katharevousa. Encyclopædia Britannica asserts that "his influence on the modern Greek language and culture ha

heading: Deaths
txt: José Bonifácio de Andrada, Brazilian poet, academic, and politician (b. 1763)

entities.title: José Bonifácio de Andrada
entities.description: José Bonifácio de Andrada e Silva was a Brazilian statesman, naturalist, mineralist, professor and poet, born in Santos, São Paulo, then part of the Portuguese Empire. He was one of the most important mentors of Brazilian independence, and his actions were decisive for the success of Emperor Pedro I. He supported public education, was an abolitionist and suggested that a new national capital be cr

heading: Deaths
txt: James Kirke Paulding, American author and politician, 11th United States Secretary of the Navy (b. 1778)

entities.title: James Kirke Paulding
entities.description: James Kirke Paulding was an American writer and, for a time, the United States Secretary of the Navy. Paulding 's early writings were satirical and violently anti-British, as shown in The Diverting History of John Bull and Brother Jonathan (1812). He wrote numerous long poems and serious histories. Among his novels are Konigsmarke, the Long Finne (1823) and The Dutchman's Fireside (1831). He is be

entities.title: United States Secretary of the Navy
entities.description: The secretary of the Navy is a statutory officer and the head of the Department of the Navy, a military department within the United States Department of Defense.

heading: Deaths
txt: Albert Sidney Johnston, American general (b. 1803)

entities.title: Albert Sidney Johnston
entities.description: Albert Sidney Johnston served as a general in three different armies: the Texian Army, the United States Army, and the Confederate States Army. He saw extensive combat during his 34-year military career, fighting actions in the Black Hawk War, the Texas War of Independence, the Mexican–American War, the Utah War, and the American Civil War.

heading: Deaths
txt: Benjamin Wright Raymond, American merchant and politician, 3rd Mayor of Chicago (b. 1801)

entities.title: Benjamin Wright Raymond
entities.description: Benjamin Wright Raymond was an American politician who twice served as mayor of Chicago, Illinois for the Whig Party.

entities.title: Mayor of Chicago
entities.description: The mayor of Chicago is the chief executive of city government in Chicago, Illinois, the third-largest city in the United States. The mayor is responsible for the administration and management of various city departments, submits proposals and recommendations to the Chicago City Council, is active in the enforcement of the city's ordinances, submits the city's annual budget and appoints city offic

heading: Deaths
txt: William Edward Forster, English businessman, philanthropist, and politician, Chief Secretary for Ireland (b. 1818)

entities.title: William Edward Forster
entities.description: William Edward Forster, PC, FRS was an English industrialist, philanthropist and Liberal Party statesman. His staunch advocacy of lethal force against the Land League earned him the nickname Buckshot Forster.

entities.title: Chief Secretary for Ireland
entities.description: The Chief Secretary for Ireland was a key political office in the British administration in Ireland. Nominally subordinate to the Lord Lieutenant, and officially the "Chief Secretary to the Lord Lieutenant", from the early 19th century until the end of British rule he was effectively the government minister with responsibility for governing Ireland, roughly equivalent to the role of a Secretary of

heading: Deaths
txt: Alvan Wentworth Chapman, American physician and botanist (b. 1809)

entities.title: Alvan Wentworth Chapman
entities.description: Alvan Wentworth Chapman was an American physician and pioneering botanist in the study of flora of the American Southeast. He wrote Flora of the Southern United States, the first comprehensive description of US plants in any region beyond the northeastern states. Chapman is a leader in the fields of hierarchy theory, systems theory, and complexity.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexander Kielland, Norwegian author, playwright, and politician, 6th County Governor of Møre og Romsdal (b. 1849)

entities.title: Alexander Kielland
entities.description: Alexander Lange Kielland was one of the most famous Norwegian realistic writers of the 19th century. He is one of the so-called "The Four Greats" of Norwegian literature, along with Henrik Ibsen, Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson and Jonas Lie.

entities.title: List of County Governors of Møre og Romsdal
entities.description: This is a list of the County Governors of Møre og Romsdal county in Norway. The office of County Governor is a government agency of the Kingdom of Norway. The title was Amtmann and then Fylkesmann.

heading: Deaths
txt: Somerset Lowry-Corry, 4th Earl Belmore (b. 1835)

entities.title: Somerset Lowry-Corry, 4th Earl Belmore
entities.description: Somerset Richard Lowry-Corry, 4th Earl Belmore,, styled as Viscount Corry from 1841 to 1845, was an Irish nobleman and Conservative politician.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kabalega, King of Bunyoro (b.1853)

entities.title: Kabalega of Bunyoro
entities.description: Chwa II Kabalega, was the ruler or Omukama of Bunyoro in Uganda from 1870 to 1899.

heading: Deaths
txt: Florence Earle Coates, American poet (b. 1850)

entities.title: Florence Earle Coates
entities.description: Florence Van Leer Earle Nicholson Coates was an American poet.

heading: Deaths
txt: Edwin Arlington Robinson, American poet and playwright (b. 1869)

entities.title: Edwin Arlington Robinson
entities.description: Edwin Arlington Robinson was an American poet. Robinson won the Pulitzer Prize for Poetry on three occasions and was nominated for the Nobel Prize in Literature four times.

heading: Deaths
txt: Rose O'Neill, American cartoonist, illustrator, artist, and writer (b. 1874)

entities.title: Rose O'Neill
entities.description: Rose Cecil O'Neill was an American cartoonist, illustrator, artist, and writer. She built a successful career as a magazine and book illustrator and, at a young age, became the best-known and highest- paid female commercial illustrator in the United States. O' Neill earned a fortune and international fame by creating the Kewpie, the most widely known cartoon character until Mickey Mouse.

entities.title: Cartoonist
entities.description: A cartoonist is a visual artist who specializes in drawing cartoons or comics. Cartoonists include the artists who handle all aspects of the work and those who contribute only part of the production. heading: Deaths
txt: Herbert Backe, German agronomist and politician (b. 1896)

entities.title: Herbert Backe
entities.description: Herbert Friedrich Wilhelm Backe was a German politician and SS functionary during the Nazi era. He was a doctrinaire racial ideologue, a long-time associate of Richard Walther Darré and a personal friend of Reinhard Heydrich. He developed and implemented the Hunger Plan that envisioned death by starvation of millions of Slavic and Jewish "useless eaters" following Operation Barbarossa, the 1941 in

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis Wilkins, American pole vaulter (b. 1882)

entities.title: Louis Wilkins
entities.description: Louis Gary Wilkins was an American athlete who competed mainly in the pole vault. He competed for the United States in the 1904 Summer Olympics held in St Louis, United States in the pole vault where he won the bronze medal.

heading: Deaths
txt: Idris Davies, Welsh poet and author (b. 1905)

entities.title: Idris Davies
entities.description: Idris Davies was a Welsh poet. Born in Rhymney, near Merthyr Tydfil in South Wales, he became a poet, originally writing in Welsh, but later writing exclusively in English.

heading: Deaths
txt: Leo Aryeh Mayer, Polish-Israeli scholar and academic (b. 1895)

entities.title: Leo Aryeh Mayer
entities.description: Leo Aryeh Mayer, was an Israeli scholar of Islamic art and rector of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jules Bordet, Belgian microbiologist and immunologist, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1870)

entities.title: Jules Bordet
entities.description: Jules Jean Baptiste Vincent Bordet was a Belgian immunologist and microbiologist. The bacterial genus Bordetella is named after him. The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded to him in 1919 for his discoveries relating to immunity.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded yearly by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institutet for outstanding discoveries in physiology or medicine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Otto Struve, Ukrainian-American astronomer and academic (b. 1897)

entities.title: Otto Struve
entities.description: Otto Struve was a Russian-American astronomer. In Russian, his name is sometimes given as Otto Lyudvigovich Struve ; however, he spent most of his life and his entire scientific career in the United States. Otto was the descendant of famous astronomers of the Struve family; he was the son of Ludwig Struve, grandson of Otto Wilhelm von Struve and great-grandson of Friedrich Georg Wilhelm von Struve

heading: Deaths
txt: Maurice Stokes, American basketball player (b. 1933)

entities.title: Maurice Stokes
entities.description: Maurice Stokes was an American professional basketball player. He played for the Cincinnati/Rochester Royals of the National Basketball Association (NBA) from 1955 to 1958. Stokes was a three-time NBA All-Star, a three-time All-NBA Second Team member and the 1956 NBA Rookie of the Year. His career – and later his life – was cut short by a debilitating brain injury and paralysis.

txt: Igor Stravinsky, Russian-American pianist, composer, and conductor (b. 1882)

entities.title: Igor Stravinsky
entities.description: Igor Fyodorovich Stravinsky was a Russian composer, pianist and conductor, later of French and American citizenship. He is widely considered one of the most important and influential composers of the 20th century.

heading: Deaths
txt: Willem Marinus Dudok, Dutch architect (b. 1884)

entities.title: Willem Marinus Dudok
entities.description: Willem Marinus Dudok was a Dutch modernist architect. He was born in Amsterdam. He became City Architect for the town of Hilversum in 1928 where he was best known for the brick Hilversum Town Hall, completed in 1931. Not only did he design the building, but also the interior including the carpets, furniture and even the mayor's meeting hammer. He also designed and built about 75 houses, public bui

heading: Deaths
txt: Hudson Fysh, Australian pilot and businessman, co-founded Qantas Airways Limited (b. 1895)

entities.title: Qantas
entities.description: Qantas Airways Limited is the flag carrier of Australia and its largest airline by fleet size, international flights and international destinations. It is the world's third-oldest airline still in operation, having been founded in November 1920; it began international passenger flights in May 1935. The Qantas name comes from "QANTAS", an acronym for its original name, Queensland and Northern Terri

heading: Deaths
txt: Kōichi Kido, Japanese politician, 13th Lord Keeper of the Privy Seal of Japan (b. 1889)

entities.title: Kōichi Kido
entities.description: Marquis Kōichi Kido  served as Lord Keeper of the Privy Seal of Japan from 1940 to 1945, and was the closest advisor to Emperor Hirohito throughout World War II. He was convicted of war crimes and sentenced to life imprisonment, of which he served 6 years before being released in 1953.

entities.title: Lord Keeper of the Privy Seal of Japan
entities.description: The Lord Keeper of the Privy Seal of Japan  was an administrative post not of Cabinet rank in the government of the Empire of Japan, responsible for keeping the Privy Seal of Japan and State Seal of Japan. The modern office of the Lord Keeper of the Privy Seal was identical with the old Naidaijin only in name and should not be confused. The office was abolished in 1945 after the Second World War.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ivan Vasilyov, Bulgarian architect, designed the SS. Cyril and Methodius National Library (b. 1893)

entities.title: Ivan Vasilyov
entities.description: Ivan Vasilyov was a Bulgarian architect, born in 1893, deceased in 1979.

entities.title: SS. Cyril and Methodius National Library
entities.description: The SS. Cyril and Methodius National Library is the national library of Bulgaria, situated in the capital city of Sofia. Founded on 4 April 1878, the library received the status of Bulgarian National Library three years later and the Bulgarian National Revival Archive was merged into it in 1924.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jayanto Nath Chaudhuri, Indian General who served as the Chief of Army Staff of the Indian Army from 1962 to 1966 and the Military Governor of Hyderabad State from 1948 to 1949. (b. 1908)

entities.title: Jayanto Nath Chaudhuri
entities.description: General Jayanto Nath Chaudhuri, was a General Officer in the Indian Army. He served as the 6th Chief of Army Staff from 1962 to 1966 and the Military Governor of Hyderabad State from 1948 to 1949. After his retirement from the Indian Army, he served as the Indian High Commissioner to Canada from 19 July 1966 until August 1969.

heading: Deaths
txt: Isaac Asimov, American science fiction writer (b. 1920)

entities.title: Isaac Asimov
entities.description: Isaac Asimov was an American writer and professor of biochemistry at Boston University. He was known for his works of science fiction and popular science. Asimov was a prolific writer, and wrote or edited more than 500 books. He also wrote an estimated 90,000 letters and postcards.

heading: Deaths
txt: Juvénal Habyarimana, Rwandan banker and politician, 3rd President of Rwanda (b. 1937)

entities.title: Juvénal Habyarimana
entities.description: Juvénal Habyarimana was a Rwandan military officer who served as the second president of Rwanda, from 1973 until 1994. He was nicknamed "Kinani", a Kinyarwanda word meaning "invincible".

entities.title: President of Rwanda
entities.description: This article lists the presidents of Rwanda since the creation of the office in 1961, to the present day. As specified in the constitution, the President functions as the head of state of Rwanda, and possesses broad executive powers. The officeholder is elected by popular vote every seven years, and appoints the Prime Minister and all other members of Cabinet.

heading: Deaths
txt: Cyprien Ntaryamira, Burundian politician, 5th President of Burundi (b. 1955)

entities.title: President of Burundi
entities.description: The president of Burundi, officially the president of the Republic, is the head of state and head of government of the Republic of Burundi. The president is also commander-in-chief of the National Defence Force. The office of the presidency was established when Michel Micombero declared Burundi a republic on 28 November 1966. The first constitution to specify the powers and duties of the president

entities.title: Ioannis Alevras
entities.description: Ioannis Alevras was a Greek Panhellenic Socialist Movement politician and Speaker of the Hellenic Parliament, who served as acting President of Greece in March 1985.

entities.title: President of Greece
entities.description: The president of the Hellenic Republic, colloquially referred to in English as the president of Greece, is the head of state of Greece. The president is elected by the Hellenic Parliament; the role has been mainly ceremonial since the 1986 constitutional reform. The office was formally established by the Constitution of Greece in 1975, but has antecedents in the Second Hellenic Republic of 1924–19

heading: Deaths
txt: Greer Garson, English-American actress (b. 1904)

entities.title: Greer Garson
entities.description: Eileen Evelyn Greer Garson was an English actress and singer. She was a major star at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer popularized during the Second World War for her portrayal of strong women on the homefront; listed by the Motion Picture Herald as one of America's top-ten box office draws from 1942 to 1946. She is the fourth most nominated woman for the Best Actress Oscar.

heading: Deaths
txt: Red Norvo, American vibraphone player and composer (b. 1908)

entities.title: Red Norvo
entities.description: Red Norvo was an American musician, one of jazz's early vibraphonists, known as "Mr. Swing". He helped establish the xylophone, marimba, and vibraphone as jazz instruments. His recordings included "Dance of the Octopus", "Bughouse", "Knockin' on Wood", "Congo Blues", and "Hole in the Wall".

heading: Deaths
txt: Habib Bourguiba, Tunisian politician, 1st President of Tunisia (b. 1903)

entities.title: Habib Bourguiba
entities.description: Habib Bourguiba was a Tunisian lawyer, nationalist leader and statesman who led the country from 1956 to 1987 as Prime minister of the Kingdom of Tunisia (1956–57) then as the first President of Tunisia (1957–87). Prior to his presidency, he led the nation to independence from France, ending the 75-year-old protectorate and earning the title of "Supreme Combatant".

entities.title: President of Tunisia
entities.description: The president of Tunisia, formally known as the president of the Republic of Tunisia, is the head of state of Tunisia. Tunisia is a semi-presidential republic, whereby the president is the head of state and the prime minister is head of government. Under Article 77 of the Constitution of Tunisia, the president is also the commander-in-chief of the Tunisian Armed Forces. The current president is Ka

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Pettigrew, American singer-songwriter (b. 1963)

entities.title: Charles Pettigrew
entities.description: Charles & Eddie were an American soul music duo composed of Charles Pettigrew and Eddie Chacon. Their single "Would I Lie to You?", taken from their 1992 debut album, Duophonic, won Ivor Novello Awards in 1993 in the Best Contemporary Song, Best Selling Song and International Hit of the Year categories. Between 1992 and 1995 they hit the top 40 three more times in the UK.

entities.title: David Bloom
entities.description: David Jerome Bloom was an American television journalist until his sudden death in 2003 after a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) became a pulmonary embolism.

entities.description: AnitaB.org is a global nonprofit organization based in Belmont, California. Founded by computer scientists Anita Borg and Telle Whitney, the institute's primary aim is to recruit, retain, and advance women in technology.

Cobb, and others. It originally aired on NBC from 1962 to 1971, for a total of 249 episodes. Filmed in color, The Virginian became television's first 90-minute Western series.
